supporting_text: The NAP lays the foundation for adopting good collaboration to address the effects of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) on humans, animals and the impact on our environment in Solomon Islands.
Objective 4: Optimize the use of antimicrobial medicines in human and animal health.
Objective 4: Optimize the use of antimicrobial medicines in human and animal health.
The NAP mentions the need for new regulations to control and contain AMR in agriculture and environment sectors.
The NAP includes actions related to the use of antimicrobials in agriculture and the need for regulations in this sector.
The NAP states that the National AMR Committee will develop an annual Operational Plan and provide quarterly and annual reports on the progress of implementation.
The NAP includes specific objectives and activities linked to indicators and targets.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The costing of this plan will be linked to the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Framework and developed in consultation with respective Ministry and donor partners.
The NAP mentions the need for annual budgetary requirements linked to an aligned results-based M&E Framework.
The National AMR Committee (NAMRC) is established to coordinate AMR activities.
The NAP includes actions to update legislation and strengthen capacities for pre-licensing safety evaluation of antimicrobials.
The NAP includes strategies to include AMR in all professional development programs.
The NAP mentions the need to conduct regular public awareness campaigns and engage with community groups.
The NAP states the government's commitment to work with WHO, FAO, and WOAH to combat AMR.
The NAP includes objectives to strengthen surveillance systems across clinics and provincial hospitals.
The NAP emphasizes the need for improved laboratory capacity for early detection and intervention.
Objective 3: Reduce the incidence of infection through effective sanitation, hygiene and infection prevention measures.
The NAP aligns with the WHO Global Action Plan and emphasizes the need for adherence to international standards.
The NAP includes actions to update regulations for all animal health products, including antibiotics.
The NAP includes actions to develop regulations to restrict and penalize the importers, prescribers, and sellers of antimicrobials.
The NAP advocates for operational research opportunities in collaboration with international partners.
